item.title: Arc Raiders Eyes In The Sky Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

If you're a fan of visiting multiple maps for a single quest in Arc Raiders, boy do we have some objectives for you. For the Eyes in the Sky quest, you'll be tasked with heading to three different maps to place LiDAR Scanners, and getting all of them done is going to take a bit of skill, luck, and a zipline. Let's talk about it.

You won't need to extract to complete any portion of Eyes in the Sky, so you can go in with a free loadout for the Dam Battlegrounds and Spaceport objectives. However, you will need a zipline to reach the necessary spot on Buried City, so you may want to suit up for that one.

When you're ready to tackle this quest, follow the guide below.

On Dam Battlegrounds, install a LiDAR Scanner at the top of the Control Tower

The first LiDAR Scanner you need to install is likely to be the most dangerous of them all. To complete this objective, you'll need to visit the high-traffic and PVP-centric Control Tower POI in the middle of the Dam Battlegrounds map.

This POI is frequently riddled with PVPers and folks trying to use their keys to open doors inside the building. With that in mind, don't be surprised if you've got to take out a few folks before you get to where you're going.

There are multiple entrances into this POI, but one of the safest options is to approach this building from the south. You should spot some stairs on the side of the building. Take them up until you reach the main floor (don't go all the way up).

Run toward the door down the long outside hallway.

Inside, continue straight to spot a breachable door. If someone has already been through here, the door may be open already, as in the photo below. If not, you'll need to breach it quickly and hope no one comes up behind you.

With the door open, you'll notice ziplines going up and down. Take the one that heads upward, but before you take it, look straight up and shoot any turrets that may be along the walls above you, as they'll rip you to shreds if you take the zipline up before they're killed.

If someone's been through here already, you may not see any turrets. This can be a good or bad thing. Since there's a very popular key room on the floor above you, it's possible someone has already gone up and entered that room, and they'll often set traps at the top of the zipline to alert them of any potential threats.

If you go up and set off any traps, it's a good idea to immediately call out that you're friendly and just questing to calm other raiders' nerves. But in cases where the person is aggressive, you may have to fight back. In the worst case scenario, you'll die and have to load back in to try again--but the best case scenario is that you eliminate someone and get some sweet loot for it.

However this situation plays out, the key room on the right in the linear corridor isn't your main goal. Instead, you'll want to make your way through the corridor until you reach another breachable door at the top of some stairs. Once it's opened, you'll have access to the Control Tower roof.

On the Control Tower roof, head forward and slightly left to spot a tripod. Approach and interact with this to place a LiDAR Scanner.

Slip back down the zipline when you're ready to extract. Just be aware that there could be raiders waiting for you at the bottom, expecting you to be full of loot from the key room above. As always, don't be surprised if a fight breaks out.

On Spaceport, install a LiDAR Scanner at the Communications Tower

The next LiDAR Scanner must be placed at the Communications Tower on the eastern side of Spaceport. This area is largely devoid of other players, so it'll almost certainly be the breeziest of the three installations.

When you arrive at the Communications Tower, simply climb the yellow ladder leading up the tower until you reach a platform.

On this platform is another tripod you can interact with to place a LiDAR Scanner.

Head back down the ladder and extract when you're ready to head back home.

On Buried City, install a LiDAR Scanner on top of the Galleria sign

The final LiDAR Scanner needs to be placed atop the Galleria sign on the eastern side of Buried City. You will need a zipline to reach this tripod. As a matter of fact, it's never a bad idea to bring a couple since putting up ziplines can sometimes be finicky, so it's good to have an extra in the event you get the placement wrong.

Approach the Galleria from the south.

Climb atop the square structures on the building just south of the Galleria.

Use the makeshift bridge up here to cross over to the Galleria rooftop.

Use your zipline to connect to the upper portion of the Galleria sign as shown in the photo below. Placing the zipline too low--such as on the protective railing--will result in you falling off rather than reaching the platform you need to be on.

Take the zipline up. You may need to jump just a bit to land correctly, as you can easily blast past the protective railing and take substantial damage if you take the zipline the full way.

Once you reach the platform, interact with the tripod up here. Check for the weapon case that frequently spawns up here for a chance at a good gun, too.

When you're ready to head home and wrap up this quest, go ahead and hit any extraction point and make your way back to Speranza.

For more on Arc Raiders quests and more, check out our comprehensive guides hub.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arc-raiders-eyes-in-the-sky-quest-guide/1100-6537230/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Arc Raiders What We Left Behind Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Arc Raiders has multiple quests that send you trekking across multiple maps, and What We Left Behind is one of them you'll encounter along the way. This quest asks you to go to Buried City, Dam Battlegrounds, and Spaceport to search for specific things, and rounding up the correct spots to visit can be a challenge if you're not familiar with the maps yet. That's alright, though--that's where we come in.

Keep in mind that, since you won't need to extract with any items to complete any steps in What We Left Behind, you can comfortably head in with a free loadout to avoid risking any of your good loot. But, of course, you're also welcome to bring your best stuff if you'd rather be ready for a fight.

When you're ready to get started, here's how to complete each step of What We Left Behind.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • On Buried City, search 2 containers in the Raider Camp beneath the Parking Garage
  • On Dam Battlegrounds, search for anything significant in the South Swamp Outpost
  • On Spaceport, search for anything significant in Bilguun's Hideout, next to the Container Storage

On Buried City, search 2 containers in the Raider Camp beneath the Parking Garage

The first part of the quest sends you to the Parking Garage on the northwestern side of Buried City. This is a common spot for folks to loot cars, so keep an eye out for other raiders.

When you arrive at the Parking Garage, walk to the first floor and look for a door labeled "01" beside it. This door will need to be breached to open it, so scout out your surroundings to make sure you're alone, then quickly breach it.

Head down the zipline inside to reach the Raider Camp. Loot any two containers in this room below the Parking Garage to complete the first step of the quest. Go ahead and extract when you're all set to head home, then you'll be set for the second portion of this adventure.

On Dam Battlegrounds, search for anything significant in the South Swamp Outpost

The second step of the quest sends you to the South Swamp Outpost on the western side of Dam Battlegrounds. This is a pretty safe and low-traffic area, but it's still a good idea to approach with caution in case any hostile raiders are also doing this quest.

When you arrive at the South Swamp Outpost, make your way into the large, round room. In this main room of the building, interact with the stack of papers below to finish this objective.

With the Dam Battlegrounds portion of things out of the way, you're all set to extract and get started on the final part of the quest.

On Spaceport, search for anything significant in Bilguun's Hideout, next to the Container Storage

The third part of the quest sends you to Bilguun's Hideout in Spaceport. This is a depot connected to the giant cement wall directly beside Container Storage, and it's not likely to be occupied in most games. As always, stay frosty just in case, though.

When you arrive, you'll spot Bilguun's Hideout above you. There's a yellow ladder leading up to the hideout, making it easy to access from the ground below.

Once inside, check the left side of the hideout for notes you can interact with.

Once you've found the notes, you can wrap the quest up by extracting, then speaking with Tian Wen back in Speranza. That was quite a series of trips--but rest assured, there are still plenty more Arc Raiders quests to face down. So, for more on this extraction shooter, have a look at our comprehensive guides hub.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arc-raiders-what-we-left-behind-quest-guide/1100-6537229/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: PlayStation Hyperpop PS5 DualSense Collection Revealed
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's the start of a new year, and you might be tempted to give your PS5 console a makeover. Fortunately, Sony has a new selection of limited-edition PS5 console covers and DualSense controllers on the way, all sporting vivid neon colors. The Hyerpop Collection PS5 console covers will be a PS Direct Store exclusive priced at $75, while the DualSense controllers will cost $85 each. Preorders will open on January 16 ahead of their March 12 launch.

Like the console covers, the DualSense controllers will be available in three distinct colorways. Techno Red is a loud, vibrant option that fades to a glossy black at the top. First released in November 2020, the DualSense controller features adaptive triggers, a built-in microphone, a 3.5mm audio jack, and a Create Button for when you want to quickly grab in-game screenshots and video clips. Remix Green also pops nicely on the DualSense controller, with this particular shade being an instant attention-grabber. While it's also a bright color, Rhythm Blue is a touch softer than the two options above it. The blue tones give the DualSense controller a slightly subdued and calmer effect.

Hyperpop Collection PS5 console covers

$75 | Releases March 12

PS5 console covers will also be available in all three Hyperpop Collection colors. These will be available for both the standard PS5 console with a disc drive and the digital edition model. These will be available exclusively through PlayStation Direct and are designed to complement the controllers.

Sony doesn't release new PS5 console covers or DualSense controller color lines like this too often. While you can usually expect to see tie-in gear for console-exclusive games or one-offs like the Icon Blue, dedicated colorways like these are rarer. So far, the line includes the Chroma Collection and the Deep Earth Collection, a series of bright and unusual colors designed to make your PS5 setup stand out.

You can still pick up several of the controllers on Amazon, and they're also cheaper than the Hyperpop Collection at $80 each. The Chroma Indigo, Chroma Teal, and Chroma Pearl controllers have been popular, with fans describing them as elegant additions to a PS5 setup thanks to their layered designs. The Deep Earth DualSense controller designs are similar to the Chroma Collection, but with an expanded color selection that includes Sterling Silver, Cobalt Blue, and Volcanic Red.

  • Chroma Collection DualSense Controllers
  • Deep Earth Collection DualSense Controllers
  • Recently Released 4K Blu-Rays Are 3 For $33 At Amazon
  • TMNT Magic: The Gathering Booster Box Preorders Steeply Discounted
  • Budget-Friendly Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds Lego Sets Are Available Now
  • + Show More More Gaming, Tech, and Entertainment Deals & Preorders Links (5)
  • Lego Harry Potter 25th Anniversary Sets Have Arrived, Including A New Collector's Edition
  • New Lego Star Wars BB-8 Droid Building Set Is Available Now
  • Double Nintendo Switch 2 Console Storage For Only $33 With Samsung MicroSD Express Deal
  • New Tom And Jerry Blu-Ray Anthology Drops To Lowest Price Yet
  • Arcade1Up Classic Special Edition Mortal Kombat Cabinet Gets First Discount

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Ubisoft Shuts Down Studio That Unionized Last Month
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

In December 2025, the developers at Ubisoft Halifax--the studio behind the mobile game Assassin's Creed Rebellion--successfully voted to unionize and join the Game & Media Workers Guild of Canada. Now, less than a month later, Ubisoft is shutting down Ubisoft Halifax and laying off 70 people.

According to Video Games Chronicle, Ubisoft has denied that the closure of the studio has anything to do with the employees' unionization efforts. The publisher also stated through a spokesperson that the decision to close Ubisoft Halifax had already been made before the union vote was taken.

"Over the past 24 months, Ubisoft has undertaken company-wide actions to streamline operations, improve efficiency, and reduce costs," Ubisoft's spokesperson said in a statement to VGC. "As part of this, Ubisoft has made the difficult decision to close its Halifax studio ... 71 positions will be affected. We are committed to supporting all impacted team members during this transition with resources, including comprehensive severance packages and additional career assistance."

Late last year, Ubisoft came under fire for asking employees to accept "voluntary career transition," or in other words, an early layoff. Assassin's Creed executive producer Marc-Alexis Côté also left the company after nearly two decades, and he has since stated that it wasn't his choice to leave.

In November, Ubisoft told investors that its earnings in Q2 of its fiscal year were up 39% year-over-year. The company also stated that the Assassin's Creed franchise exceeded its expectations. That apparently wasn't enough to prevent any further job losses at its partner studios.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Call Of Duty's Fallout Crossover Adds A Vault-Themed Nuketown, LTMs, And Skins
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Season 1 Reloaded arrives in Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 and Warzone on January 8, and the big midseason update adds a crossover event with the Fallout TV series. This includes Fallout-themed skins, limited-time game modes, and an event pass.

This midseason update is bringing the wasteland to Black Ops 7 and Warzone with an all-new Fallout event. As shown in the trailer above, this event will feature operator skins for Lucy, Maximus, and The Ghoul from Amazon Prime Video's Fallout TV show. The event also includes additional vault dweller skins.

This Fallout event follows the formula of Call of Duty's other major IP events, such as the TMNT and Squid Game crossovers, offering both free and paid event passes filled with cosmetic rewards. Call of Duty's paid event passes usually cost $10. The Ghoul and Maximus are available to unlock in the paid event pass, while the vault dweller skins are earned in the free pass. Lucy's operator skin is available as a shop bundle, and Call of Duty's operator bundles are typically around $20 each.

Call of Duty will feature three limited-time game modes themed around the Fallout series. Ghoul Infection is a limited-time multiplayer mode that puts a Fallout spin on Call of Duty's Infection game mode. Project RADs is a ghoul-themed Zombies mode, and Warzone features Power-Armor Royale, which lets players step into Fallout's power armor and wield miniguns in battle royale.

Treyarch's popular Nuketown map is also getting a makeover for the big event. This gives a Fallout-themed design to the map, with the mannequins dressed up in blue vault suits.

Make sure to check out all the details for Season 1 Reloaded in Black Ops 7 and Warzone, including more weapons, multiplayer maps, and a mystery to solve in Warzone.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/call-of-dutys-fallout-crossover-adds-a-vault-themed-nuketown-ltms-and-skins/1100-6537255/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Arc Raiders A Bad Feeling Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Arc Raiders quests can sometimes get pretty complicated, demanding you venture across multiple maps to complete various objectives. A Bad Feeling isn't one of these, though, as it asks something quite simple of you: Just open an Arc Probe or Arc Courier. But where exactly will you find one of these, and what will you find inside? We're here to answer that for you, so read on for where to find Arc Probes and Arc Couriers.

Where to find Arc Probes

You may occasionally see a fresh Arc Probe come in from the sky (keep an eye out for something that looks like a rocket coming down). These will be standing straight up once they land. However, these aren't likely to be the probes you normally come across, as most Arc Probes are found tipped over on their sides. In either case, you can hear Arc Probes from some distance--listen for their odd bleeps and bloops emitting every few seconds.

While they're found in randomized spots all across every map, Arc Probes are considerably more common during the Electromagnetic Storm map event. During the event, check the roof of the Testing Annex on the Dam Battlegrounds map to score at least 2-3 of them in the same spot--which is a great way to start getting your points up if you're trying to knock out an Open Arc Probes weekly trial that may be active.

Alternatively, keep an eye out for the Prospecting Probes event to pop up when you're selecting a map to visit. Prospecting Probes pops up occasionally on each map except Stella Montis, and you'll be able to tell it's active by hovering over the map with your cursor. During this event, Arc Probes will be plentifully scattered across the map, so you certainly won't have any problems finding as many as you need.

Arc Probes typically contain items like Arc Alloy, Arc Circuitry, and Arc Motion Cores--all of which are needed for crafting items. This makes Arc Probes worth popping open if you're invested in crafting much of your loadout--though you'll likely find the loot inside fairly insignificant otherwise.

Where to find Arc Couriers

Like Arc Probes, Arc Couriers can be found in random spots all across the map and similarly emit a black smoke. And also, just like Arc Probes, these are usually easier to find during the Electromagnetic Storm map condition. While the spawn locations vary, we've had a lot of luck finding Arc Couriers in the Red Lakes on the eastern side of Dam Battlegrounds.

Arc Couriers can often house some important materials you'll need for progression, too. Specifically, keep an eye out for Surveyor Vaults and Sentinel Firing Cores when opening these, as you'll need them to craft some of your workbenches. Since the only other way to get these items is killing Surveyors or Sentinels--both of which are in very limited supply on each map--popping open Arc Couriers may turn out to be a quicker method than farming the enemies themselves.

In both cases, sometimes breaching these containers spawns a sudden drop of Arc enemies such as hornets and wasps.

Once you've looted an Arc Probe or Arc Courier, you'll be able to turn in the A Bad Feeling quest back in Speranza. But finding one of these drops is just the beginning of your journey topside. There's plenty more to come as you work your way through the quests in Arc Raiders, so visit our comprehensive guides hub to learn more.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arc-raiders-a-bad-feeling-quest-guide/1100-6537227/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Arc Raiders Back On Top Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Quests in Arc Raiders most frequently require you to visit only one map, but you'll occasionally encounter some that send you across multiple maps to complete them. One of these quests is Back on Top, which asks you to visit all four launch maps and mark specific buildings. It's not a particularly challenging quest, but it can be rather time consuming due to the amount of travel time needed to reach each building on the maps. As such, we've compiled the locations of all four buildings you need to mark. When you're ready to get this quest underway, follow the steps below.

Mark the Pattern House

The Pattern House is located at the northern tip of the Dam Battlegrounds map. Head to the wall right beside the entrance and mark it to finish this portion of this quest.

This area is generally safe, but you should probably still keep your gun in hand if you plan to meander around inside and loot after marking it.

Mark the white lookout tower

The white lookout tower is located around the center of the Blue Gate map. Approach it and tag the wall to finish up this part of the quest.

Due to its proximity to the Overlook Airshaft extraction point and Checkpoint POI, you may run into some folks in the area, so be prepared for a fight if your lobbies tend to be aggressive.

Mark the South Trench Tower

The South Trench Tower is located in the northern section of the Spaceport map. Walk up to it and mark one of the supporting walls at the bottom to complete this section of the quest.

This tower, as well as the North Trench Tower directly across from it, require keycards to enter. With this in mind, keep an eye out for anyone who may be looking to use their key, as they'll likely be wary of anyone hanging around nearby.

Mark the building with the mural

The building with the mural is located on the eastern side of the Buried City map. Waltz right up and spray it to wrap up this part of the quest.

This area is likely to be pretty safe, though the nearby Galleria can occasionally be home to raiders looking to pick a fight. But hey, if they do, just finish it for them and take some loot for your troubles.

Once all four buildings have been marked, you'll be able to return to Speranza and turn this quest in. The reward of a Renegade, Stable Stock III, and some Medium Ammo may feel a bit underwhelming after all of that traveling, but at least you're ready to start knocking out the rest of the Arc Raiders quest list--which means you'll want to take a look at our comprehensive guides hub.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arc-raiders-back-on-top-quest-guide/1100-6537224/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: 20 Years Later, An Xbox 360 Collector Finally Finishes Their $20,000 Game Library
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Some collectors will stop at nothing to complete their collections, even if that means decades have to pass before ever finishing. One such collector was on such a journey, finding and acquiring every Xbox 360 game released, and at the start of this year, that collector has finally finished this now vintage library that totals around $20,000--with the last game being a gift from their son.

Redditor uncleseeth shared their massive library in a post on the r/gaming subreddit on January 2. Starting the collection after receiving their Xbox 360 and Neversoft's Western shooter Gun on Christmas Day in 2005, uncleseeth then went on a mad hunt for every single game ever released on Microsoft's seventh-generation console. From standard editions to different variants, uncleseeth said their collection topped at 1,353 games--well over the 1,256 needed for a "complete set," which doesn't include the variants of various games.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: 11 Best Games You Missed In 2025

Some games and items were given as gifts, including Efecto Studios' racer El Chavo Kart and the Xbox stand. One game that shocked them to find was The Farm 51's action-adventure Deadfall Adventures, which they described as "kinda [having] Indiana Jones vibes."

But the final title they were missing was Pro Evolution Soccer 2018, which was gifted to them by their son. With that in their possession, the collection was complete and totals roughly $20,000, as the games are estimated to resell for about $15 each after two decades. That said, there is one expensive game in the bunch: F1 2013, which uncleseeth approximated is going for $250 or so.

With an Xbox 360 Elite--their first Xbox 360 got the dreaded Red Ring of Death--and a total gamerscore of 497,000, uncleseeth's next goal is to continue chasing more variants and play through the entire library. They said they've played about 800 of the games but only completed roughly 175 of them. That's a lot of games to play.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
